info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 2:37PM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...POTENTIAL WINTER STORM THANKSGIVING DAY THROUGH FRIDAY... Forecast models have been trending more and more towards a winter storm impacting New Mexico Thanksgiving Day through Friday and into Friday night. At this time, mainly eastern and portions of central New Mexico would be affected but considerable uncertainty exists with the track and timing of this storm system. Strong north winds are expected to blow into northeast New Mexico Wednesday night and proceed south through the east central and southeast plains Thursday. The gusty winds will usher in substantially colder air, although not as cold as the Arctic airmass eastern New Mexico recently experienced. However highs over the east Thanksgiving Day will range from 15 to 25 degrees colder compared to Wednesday`s highs while lesser cooling is expected over western New Mexico. Along with the wind, snow and patchy blowing snow is expected to develop early Thanksgiving Day over northeast New Mexico. Rain over the east central and southeast will turn to snow by Thursday night. At this time, snow accumulations through Friday may range from one to 4 inches, with the higher amounts along Raton Pass, as well as over the Sacramento and Capitan Mountains and over portions of the east central and southeast plains. As previously stated, considerable uncertainty exists with the track and timing of this storm system. Wintry travel impacts would be more significant especially if the center of circulation tracks farther into central or even western New Mexico and the system lingers into Saturday over the eastern plains. Those who are planning to travel across New Mexico, especially the eastern portion of the state, should stay informed of the latest weather forecast at weather.gov/abq. You can find the latest road conditions at nmroads.com
